Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G02

courses.description: This course introduces key concepts, theories and models in the study of policy sciences. To resolve complex and multi-level public problems of a globalized world in ways that help to identify and enhance the common interest, policy sciences provide an integrated and interdisciplinary approach for making good policy decisions. This course also aims to help students understand the process and structure in designing policies. The concerns of this course are integrating theory and practice into actionable social knowledge and apply it to real world problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Policy Sciences and public policy
2. Basic concepts & theories in Policy Sciences
3. Key models and frameworks in Policy Analysis
4. Wicked problems & international affairs in the globalized world
5. Integrated and interdisciplinary approach for policy-making
6. Main process and structure in designing and evaluating policies
7. Theories and its application in the context of Hong Kong and comparative contexts
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
- Howlett, M., Ramesh, M., & Perl, A. (2009). Studying public policy: Policy cycles and policy subsystems (Vol. 3). Oxford: Oxford University Press.
- Sabatier, P. A., & Weible, C. M. (Eds.). (2014). Theories of the policy process. Westview Press.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Birkland, T. A. (2015). An introduction to the policy process: Theories, concepts, and models of public policy making. Routledge.
- Hajer, M., Hajer, M. A., & Wagenaar, H. (Eds.). (2003). Deliberative policy analysis: understanding governance in the network society. Cambridge University Press.
- Innes, J. E., & Booher, D. E. (2010). Planning with complexity: An introduction to collaborative rationality for public policy. Routledge.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Data Science and Public Policy
courses.description: This course focuses on the important connection between data science and public policy by identifying and analyzing the policy challenges posed by data science technologies. It assesses what policy options and tools are available to address them and examines what new capacities governments and also citizens must develop in the era of data science. Students would also be introduced to the professional and ethical responsibilities and social, economic, political and legal impacts under the changes and innovations brought by data science.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course is expected to achieve the following outcomes for the students:
Good knowledge of the fundamental concepts, major intellectual and competing perspectives in the study of data science and policy studies
Awareness of the importance of the role of data science in society, including its opportunities and threats
Appreciation of the competing perspectives and contrasting views from major stakeholders on issues and problems of data science and policy studies and realization of the assumptions behind
Ability to think critically and analytically on public issues and policy challenges related to data science
Ability to apply the concepts and theories learnt in the course to formulate solutions to address real-world problems at a policymaking level
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics to be covered included:
Introduction and Overview: Technology and Public Policy - Normative Policymaking vs. Positive Policymaking
Part I: Theoretical Foundation and Analytical Framework
This section would define data science, which is an interdisciplinary field that uses scientific and statistical methods, processes, algorithms, and systems including big data and advanced computer technologies such as AI and IoT (Internet of Things) to generate knowledge and insights from data, and provides the theoretical framework for understanding and evaluating its impacts on policymaking.
The Rise of Data Science and Disruptive Technology
Evidence-Based Policymaking
Programme Implementation and Diffusion of Technology
Part II: Technology and Policy Challenges
This section introduces the major inventions and trends in data science such as Big Data, which is dataset that cannot be stored, captured, managed and analyzed by means of conventional database software, and examines their impacts and implications on policymaking. In addition, the challenges of other discoveries such as open data, open innovation, and AI, for government and society would also be examined.
Big Data and Policymaking
Open Data and Open Innovation
AI and the Future of Work
Data Science and State Surveillance
Part III: Technology and Societal Impact
This section would discuss how data connectivity enabled by information and communication technologies (ICT) affects social and political lives. For example, smart city is a city that uses ICT to increase operational efficiency, share information with the public and improve both the quality of government services and citizen welfare. We would identify the issues and factors dividing the success and failure in the adoption and effects of those technologies.
Smart City
Social Media and Society
Social Media and Governance
Design Thinking and Public Participation

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Foundation of Data Science
courses.description: This course is intended for students with little or no programming experience. It is designed to provide students with a firm foundation for learning modern data science, which uses computer programming to wrangle and analyze data. Adopting a hands-on approach, this course covers all the basics of programming in Python, as well as general computer programming concepts and techniques, such as branching, looping and inheritance. It also familiarizes students with some of the most useful Python libraries for data science, such as NumPy, pandas and matplotlib. This course plays a foundational role in the data science curriculum.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Understand the role computation can play in solving problems.
Understand the basic programming concepts and techniques.
Write programs in Python that allow them to accomplish useful goals.
Use Python libraries to complete simple data science tasks.
courses.course_syllabus:
Values and Variables
Simple Data Types: int, float, string, boolean
Lists
Conditional Statements: if, if-else, if-elif-else
Dictionaries
User Input
Iteration: for loops, while loops
Functions and Modules
Classes and Objects
Files
Exceptions
Python libraries for data science: NumPy, pandas, matplotlib.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Statistics for Data Science and Policy Studies
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to data science and its applications in policy analysis. Students will learn the fundamental concepts of statistics and probability theory and their role in policy research. Through hands-on exercises and case studies, students will gain practical experience in descriptive statistics, probability distributions, statistical inference, and analysis. Students will also develop skills in communicating statistical results to policy audiences through effective writing and data visualization techniques. By the end of the course, students will have a solid understanding of statistical methods commonly used in policy analysis and be able to apply them to real-world problems in policy studies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Analyze and interpret policy data using descriptive statistics and statistical inference techniques.
Apply appropriate statistical tests, such as t-tests and ANOVA, to policy data to answer research questions.
Demonstrate proficiency in communicating statistical results to policy audiences through effective writing and data visualization techniques.
Apply statistical techniques to solve real-world problems in policy analysis and data science.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to Data Science, Statistics, and Policy Analysis
Overview of data science and policy analysis
Role of statistics in policy analysis
Descriptive Statistics
Measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode)
Measures of variability (range, variance, standard deviation)
Probability distributions and histograms
Box plots and scatter plots
Probability distributions
Basic concepts of probability theory
Discrete and continuous probability distributions
Random variables and expected values
Inferential Statistics
Sampling distributions and the central limit theorem
Point estimation and interval estimation
Hypothesis testing and p-values
Statistical power and effect size
Type I and Type II errors
Choice of Statistical Tests
For example: T-test, ANOVA, and Chi-square test
Regression and Prediction
Correlation analysis
Simple linear regression analysis
Communicating Statistical Results in a Policy Context
Writing statistical reports for policy audiences
Creating effective data visualizations for policy audiences
Interpreting and communicating statistical results for policy audiences
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
Bruce, P. C., Bruce, A., & Gedeck, P. (2020).
Practical statistics for data scientists : 50+ essential concepts using R and Python (Second edition.)
. O’Reilly Media, Inc.
courses.recommended_readings:
Salcedo, J. (2017).
Basic Statistics and Data Mining for Data Science (1st edition)
. Packt Publishing. [Video]
Rahman, A. (2020).
Statistics for Data Science and Policy Analysis (A. Rahman, Ed.; 1st ed. 2020.).
Springer Singapore.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Research Methods for Policy Studies
courses.description: This course introduces major methods used in policy studies research, with both quantitative and qualitative methods as the foci. This course discusses major methodological issues, stages and process of research, the use of appropriate methods, strategies and tools with the objective of enabling students to adopt a multimethod and critical approach to conduct research of public policies and data science. Course contents also include the interpretation and communication of findings to different stakeholders, research ethics and limitations, and using research to generate impact.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Introduction to major methods used in policy studies research (both quantitative and qualitative methods)
2) Theories and concepts of research principles and design
3) Knowledge of major statistical methods widely used in policy studies
4) Skills and methods in qualitative and quantitative analysis
5) Multimethod and critical approach to conduct research of public policies and data science
6) Ethics and social responsibilities of policy research
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
- Neuman, W. L. (2013). Social research methods: Qualitative and quantitative approaches. Pearson education.
- Majchrzak, A., & Markus, M. L. (2014). Methods for Policy Research. CA: Sage.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Bryman, A. (2016). Social research methods. NY: Oxford university press.
- Denzin, N. K., & Lincoln, Y. S. (1994). Handbook of qualitative research. CA: Sage.
- Singleton Jr, R., Straits, B. C., Straits, M. M., & McAllister, R. J. (1988). Approaches to social research. NY: Oxford University Press.
- Spencer, L., & Ritchie, J. (2002). Qualitative data analysis for applied policy research. In Analyzing qualitative data (pp. 187-208). NY: Routledge.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Introduction to Data Science Applications in Public Policy and Political Studies
courses.description: This introductory course explores the intersection of data science, public policy, and political studies. Students will learn how to utilize data analysis methods to understand and analyze public policy issues and the political process. The course will cover basic concepts in data science, including data collection, cleaning, analysis, and visualization, with a focus on applications in policy and political studies. Students will also learn how to critically evaluate and interpret data to inform decision-making in the public policy and political domains. Through hands-on projects and laboratory sessions, students will develop practical skills in using data to address real-world policy challenges and political issues. By the end of the course, students will be equipped with the tools and knowledge to apply data science techniques to analyze and understand the complexities of public policy and the political landscape.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
1. Understand the foundational principles of data science and how they can be applied to analyze public policy issues and political processes.
2. Develop proficiency in data collection, cleaning, analysis, and visualization techniques relevant to policy and political studies.
3. Critically evaluate and interpret data to draw meaningful insights and make informed decisions in the context of public policy and political analysis.
4. Apply data science methods to address real-world policy challenges and political issues, demonstrating the ability to use data-driven approaches to inform and shape policy decisions.
courses.course_syllabus:
Explore Data Science in Public Policy and Political Studies
Build Critical Analysis and Evidence-Based Reasoning Skills
Master Techniques for Collecting and Preparing Data
Utilize Effective Data Visualization for Clear Communication
Study Real-World Case Studies in Data-Driven Policy
Collaborate on Projects Addressing Current Policy Challenges
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
- Agresti, A., Franklin, C. A., Klingenberg, B. (2016). Statistics: The art and science of learning from data. 4th ed. NY: Pearson.
- Gorard, S. (2003). Quantitative methods in social science research. NY: Continuum.
- Miller, J. D. (2017). Statistics for Data Science. UK: Packt.
courses.recommended_readings:

Krieg, E. (2020). Statistics and data analysis for social science. (Vols. 1-0). SAGE Publications, Inc., https://doi.org/10.4135/9781071909546

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Intermediate Data Science Applications in Public Policy and Political Studies
courses.description: This intermediate course serves as a continuation of the exploration of data science methods in the context of public policy and political studies. Students will delve deeper into data analysis techniques and their application to understanding policy issues and political processes. The course is designed to further develop students' skills in data visualization, statistical analysis, and data interpretation, with a specific focus on their relevance to policy formulation and political decision-making. Through hands-on projects and laboratory sessions, students will enhance their data science proficiency and learn how to effectively communicate data-driven insights to stakeholders in the public sector. By the end of the course, students will be equipped to apply intermediate data science techniques to analyze and address policy challenges and political dynamics, building upon the foundational knowledge gained in the introductory course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
Develop proficiency in applying data analysis techniques and statistical tools to analyze complex public policy issues and political dynamics.
Enhance critical thinking skills to interpret data analysis results and formulate policy recommendations based on insights.
Cultivate an understanding of the ethical implications and impacts of data-driven approaches on policy decisions and political processes.
Demonstrate individual thinking and creative problem-solving abilities by utilizing data science methods to address policy and political challenges.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduce Advanced Statistical Analysis Techniques for Public Policy
Explore Predictive Modeling for Forecasting Policy Outcomes
Utilize Advanced Data Visualization for Complex Data Communication
Discuss Ethics in Data Science and Public Policy
Engage in Collaborative Workshops on Real-World Policy Issues
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
Urdinez, F., & Cruz, A. (2020). R for Political Data Science: A Practical Guide (1st ed.). Chapman and Hall/CRC. https://doi.org/10.1201/9781003010623
Moody, R., & Bekkers, V. (2023) Big Data and Public Policy: Course, Content and Outcome (1st ed.). Palgrave Macmillan Cham. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-16031-8.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Advanced Programming for Data Science
courses.description: This course is designed for students with prior programming experience interested in learning C# programming and game development. The course covers fundamental programming concepts like object-oriented programming, control structures, collections, and error handling in C#. Students will also learn how to create games with Unity, including working with the Unity editor, physics engine, game assets, and game AI.The course begins with an introduction to C# programming language and control structures and gradually progresses to advanced programming concepts, such as inheritance and polymorphism. Additionally, students will learn how to handle errors and debug code.The second half of the course focuses on Unity game development. Students will learn to use the Unity editor to create game objects, scenes, and gameplay mechanics. They will also learn to work with some of Unity's built-in features, e.g., animations, particle effects, and game AI.By the end of the course, students will have the skills and knowledge necessary to write a C# program and build a fully functional and engaging game with Unity.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Apply object-oriented programming concepts to develop C# programs.
Use C# to create basic programs
Analyze and troubleshoot code using debugging tools and techniques.
Create video games using Unity game engine and C# programming language.
Implement game design principles to improve player experience and gameplay mechanics.
courses.course_syllabus:
Object-Oriented Programming:
Introduction to object-oriented programming concepts, such as inheritance and polymorphism.
Defining and using classes in C#, including constructors and access modifiers.
Understanding and using interfaces, abstract classes, and virtual methods.
Working with inheritance and polymorphism in C#.
C# Programming:
Understanding the basics of C# syntax and structure.
Understanding data types and operators in C#.
Using selection statements (if/else) and loops (for/while/do-while).
Introduction to collections and generic programming.
Processing data with C# methods and functions.
Handling errors and debugging in C#.
Unity Game Development:
Understanding the Unity editor and its components.
Creating game objects and scenes in Unity.
Working with Unity's physics engine and creating physics-based interactions.
Using Unity’s built-in assets, such as animations and particle effects.
Understanding the basics of game design, including gameplay mechanics and player experience.
Introduction to game AI and decision-making.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Data Preprocessing for Data Analytics
courses.description: This course teaches students the major computing applications and coding languages, such as Python, of data analytics and how to apply them in public policy. The emphasis of the course is to apply data analytics to make theory-guided and data-driven policy decisions. With the technical competence provided by the course, students are expected to be both a skillful user of data analytics and an intelligent policymaker informed by data science. This course focuses on the data preprocessing stage in the data science lifecycle and teaches the efficient use of powerful tools for data preprocessing such as pandas.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to acquire the basic knowledge of computing applications and coding languages, such as Python, of data analytics and apply it to solve problems in public policy.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Introduction to data analytics for public policy
2) Quantitative research design and basic methods for analysis
3) Understanding the application of major computing applications and coding languages, such as Python
4) Basic knowledge in data collecting, data cleaning and analysis
5) Interpreting research results in different models
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
- Chen, D. (2022). Pandas for Everyone: Python Data Analysis (2nd edition). Addison-Wesley.
- Dunleavy, P., & Margetts, H. (2015). Design principles for essentially digital governance.
- Milan, S., & ten Oever, N. (2017). Coding and encoding rights in internet infrastructure. Internet Policy Review, 6(1).
- Raschka, S., & Mirjalili, V. (2017). Python machine learning. Packt Publishing Ltd.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Database Systems for Data Science
courses.description: This course covers the fundamental concepts of database systems and their role in data science projects. Students will gain practical experience working with relational databases, as well as learn how to design effective data models and optimize database performance. Topics covered may include SQL basics, entity-relationship modeling, normalization, indexing, and query optimization. This course is ideal for individuals with prior programming experience interested in learning about databases for data science.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Create effective data models using entity-relationship diagrams and normalization techniques.
Write SQL queries to retrieve and manipulate data from relational databases.
Evaluate the performance of database systems.
Apply database systems to real-world examples.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to Databases and Data Management
Overview of database systems and their role in data science
Relational databases and their components
Data models, data schemas, and data types
SQL basics for data retrieval and manipulation
Data Modeling and Normalization
Entity-relationship modeling and diagramming
Normalization and data redundancy
Relational database design principles
SQL for Data Science
SELECT statements and basic data retrieval
Filtering and sorting data
Joins and subqueries
Aggregation functions and grouping
Data modification statements (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE)
Advanced Topics and Future Trends in Database Technologies
Database security and data privacy
Database administration (e.g., backup and recovery strategies and user management)
Database optimization (e.g., indexing, table partitioning and sharding, and query optimization)
NoSQL databases and big data systems
Data warehousing and business intelligence
Case Studies and Practical Applications
Real-world examples of databases in data science
Data governance and ethics
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Policy Analysis and Design Thinking
courses.description: This course integrates public policy analysis and design thinking to give students an integrated and comprehensive approach of resolving public problems. Design thinking, with its key features of being solution-based, user involvement, co-creation of knowledge, co-evolution of solution and problem, complements the economics-based and analytical model of public policy analysis well. Together they strengthen students’ ability in serving the dual role of a capable policy designer and an effective analyst who solve the policy problem and satisfy the diverse concerns of stakeholders.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Basic knowledge in public policy analysis (key concepts, major theories, main methods)
2) Integrated and comprehensive approach in resolving public problem from a design thinking perspective
3) Process of policy making, understanding key factors (e.g., common interest, stakeholders, interest groups, etc.）
4) Understanding actors in policy design, their roles, and interaction dynamics
5) Acquiring knowledge about analytical model of public policy analysis
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
- Brown, T. (2009). Change by Design: How Design Thinking Transforms Organizations and Inspires Innovation. NY: Harper Collins.
- Dunn, W. N. (2015). Public policy analysis. NY: Routledge.
- Weimer, D. L., & Vining, A. R. (2017). Policy analysis: Concepts and practice. NY: Routledge.
courses.recommended_readings:

- Sabatier, P. A., & Weible, C. M. (Eds.). (2014). Theories of the policy process. CA: Westview Press.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: AI Governance and Public Policy
courses.description: The course offers an insightful and comprehensive exploration of the dynamic landscape surrounding the governance and public policies of artificial intelligence (AI). By focusing on the intersection of AI, governance, and public policy, it empowers students to navigate the multifaceted challenges. Through a combination of theoretical analysis, case studies, and interactive discussions, students will develop a profound understanding of AI strategies and governance frameworks and the formulation of responsible public policies in both national and global contexts. The course will equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary to shape the future of AI in the role of policymaker and major stakeholders in civil society.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Develop a comprehensive understanding of AI strategies and governance in both national and global contexts.
Analyze and evaluate different AI governance frameworks and strategies, considering their effectiveness and impact on transparency, fairness, accountability, and other important public values.
Apply critical thinking skills to assess the potential risks and benefits associated with AI technologies and their implementation, and propose responsible policies to mitigate those risks.
Demonstrate knowledge of the competing concerns and dilemmas related to AI such as privacy, data security, economic growth, and ethical considerations, and formulate policies that address them.
Engage in interdisciplinary discussions and collaborations to address the complex challenges at the intersection of AI, governance, and public policy.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to AI Governance and Public Policy
Overview of AI technologies and their impact on governance and public policy
Role of AI in shaping public policies
2. Transparency, Fairness, and Bias in AI
Understanding the importance of transparency and explain ability in AI systems
Assessing and mitigating biases in AI algorithms and decision-making processes
Policies for ensuring fairness and accountability in AI governance
3. Ethical Frameworks and Accountability for AI Governance
Examination of ethical principles and guidelines in AI governance
Ethical considerations in AI decision-making and algorithmic accountability
4. Legal and Regulatory Landscape for AI
Analysis of existing laws and regulations applicable to AI technologies
Privacy concerns in AI applications and data-driven decision-making
Policy frameworks for AI regulation and legal challenges in governing AI
5. AI Governance in a Global Perspective
Major paradigms, models, and approaches in AI governance
AI governance in major regions and countries (e.g., China, US, and Europe)
6. AI Governance and Public Sector Applications
AI deployment in government services and public administration
Policy considerations for AI adoption in public sector decision-making
7. Stakeholder Engagement and Collaboration in AI Governance
Engaging with diverse stakeholders in AI governance processes
Multi-stakeholder collaborations for inclusive and participatory decision-making
Building partnerships between governments, industry, academia, and civil society
8. Future Trends and Emerging Issues in AI Governance
Exploring the evolving landscape of AI technologies and their governance challenges
Policy implications and strategies for adapting to future AI advancements
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Managing Technology and Policy Innovation
courses.description: This course explores the dynamic intersection of technology and policy innovation, delving into theories and practical strategies essential for effective management. The course unfolds in two distinct parts, each addressing pivotal aspects of this interdisciplinary field. Firstly, it examines policy challenges stemming from technological advancements. Secondly, it investigates using policy to foster societal innovation. Students will gain insights into the interplay of technology, institutions, and society, essential for sustainable innovation. This course is ideal for students who are eager to understand and navigate the intricate relationship between technology and policy, and who seek to drive impactful innovation in a rapidly evolving societal landscape.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
a. Identify and understand key literature and theories on innovation in the public sector
b. Understand the interplay of technology and policy innovation
c. Identify the major factors driving the result and performance of innovation
d. Draw experience from both local and global perspectives in analyzing cases of technology and innovation
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Technology and Policy Challenges (e.g., AI and the Future of Work)
2) Technology and Societal Impact (e.g., Social Media and Governance)
3) Theories and strategies of managing technology and policy innovation
4) Innovation system and innovation policies (e.g., mechanism and process of innovation and diffusion of technology)
5) Case studies in technology innovation and policy innovation
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Data Science Project Management
courses.description: Effective project management can lead to heightened efficiency and productivity while also mitigating the risk of failure. However, overseeing data science projects poses unique challenges due to the involvement of stakeholders from multiple teams and the necessity to balance both business and technical objectives. This course provides a comprehensive overview of the intersection between project management and data science. Students will explore how project management principles can enhance the management of data science projects and how data science methodologies can improve project management practices. While no prerequisites are required, this course is ideal for students who possess a basic understanding of data science. It is particularly suitable for students who harbor an interest in effectively managing data science projects and assembling teams.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Identify and describe fundamental project management knowledge and concepts.
Apply project management principles to enhance the efficiency and productivity of data science projects.
Explain the value of project management processes, tools and techniques.
Critically assess case studies and real-world examples to understand the symbiotic relationship between project management and data science.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to Project Management and Data Science.
Overview of project management principles
Understanding what you can do with data science
Understanding the intersection of project management and data science
Leveraging Project Management for Data Science Projects.
Project initiation and planning for data science initiatives
Exploring data science team roles and their responsibility
Scope definition and requirements gathering in data science projects
Risk management and mitigation strategies in data science project planning
Resource allocation and scheduling for data science projects
Exploring the common pitfalls of data science projects.
Case Studies and Applications
Analyzing case studies of successful integration of project management and data science
Exploring industry-specific applications and best practices
Future Trends and Emerging Technologies.
Emerging trends in project management and data science
Utilizing data analytics for project forecasting and trend analysis
Impact of artificial intelligence and automation on project management processes
Ethical considerations and challenges in the convergence of project management and data science
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Linear Algebra for Data Science
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with the essential foundational concepts of modern linear algebra for understanding contemporary data science and machine learning techniques. Stressing on intuition from coding rather than traditional mathematical proofs, this course approaches linear algebra from a computational perspective, where linear algebra concepts are implemented in Python code with a focus on applications in data science and machine learning. This course is ideal for students with prior programming experience who are interested in understanding modern linear algebra and its applications in data science and machine learning from a computational perspective.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Understand what modern linear algebra is and why it is relevant and important to data science and machine learning.
Understand the core concepts and methods of modern linear algebra, such as vectors, matrices, general linear models, and singular value decomposition.
Implement modern linear algebra concepts and methods in Python code.
Apply modern linear algebra concepts and methods to solve problems in data science and machine learning, such as clustering and dimensionality reduction.

Applications in Data Science and Machine Learning

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Calculus for Data Science
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with the essential foundational concepts of calculus for understanding contemporary machine learning and data science algorithms in which calculus is used as an optimization tool. It approaches calculus, both single-variable and multivariate, from a computational perspective, stressing on intuition from coding rather than traditional mathematical proofs. This course is ideal for students with prior programming experience who are interested in understanding the powerful optimization algorithms used in modern data science and machine learning.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Understand what calculus is and why it is relevant and important to machine learning and data science.
Do differentiation and verify the result of differentiation with a computer.
Understand Jacobian, Hessian, and Laplacian matrix, and their application in machine learning algorithms.
Understand the chain rule and use it in the backpropagation algorithm.
Apply calculus techniques to build neural network training algorithms, optimal regressors, and support vector machine classifiers.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Big Data Analytics for Public Policy
courses.description: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of Big Data computing systems and programming models. Students will gain hands-on experience working with mainstream open-source platforms for Big Data processing and analytics, including Hadoop and Spark. The course covers the architecture and components of Hadoop and Spark, data processing with Spark, and advanced topics such as Spark Streaming, graph processing, and machine learning. Students will learn to develop operational and programming tools for data collection, serialization, migration, and workflow coordination in Big Data pipelines. By the end of the course, students will be able to design and implement solutions to real-world Big Data problems using Hadoop or Spark. This course is ideal for students with prior programming and database experience interested in developing expertise in Big Data computing systems and programming models for processing and analyzing large-scale datasets.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to
Apply programming models and design patterns to build scalable Big Data systems using Hadoop and Spark.
Analyze and evaluate the architecture and resource management of Big Data computing systems for optimal performance.
Utilize high-level Big Data query languages and processing systems to extract insights from large, diverse data sets.
Develop effective operational and programming tools for data collection, serialization, migration, and workflow coordination in Big Data pipelines.
Design and implement solutions to real-world Big Data problems using Hadoop or Spark.

Introduction to Big Data
Refreshing students’ knowledge of big data
Overview of big data and its challenges
Overview of commonly used big data tools
Use cases of big data
Distributed Computing and Hadoop
Overview of distributed computing and parallel processing
Hadoop architecture and its various components
Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) and its characteristics
MapReduce programming model and its use in processing large datasets
Spark Basics
Overview of Spark architecture and components
Resilient Distributed Datasets (RDDs) and their properties
Introduction to Spark SQL and DataFrames for data processing
Data Processing with Spark
Data processing concepts for structured and unstructured data
Data ingestion and ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) techniques
Transformations and actions in Spark for data manipulation
Join, aggregation, and grouping operations for data analysis
Spark Programming
Overview of Spark Streaming for real-time data processing
Graph processing using Spark GraphX
Introduction to machine learning with Spark MLlib
Integration with external databases and systems for big data processing
Big Data Ecosystem
Overview of other Big Data technologies and frameworks
NoSQL databases and their use cases in big data processing
Introduction to Apache Kafka for data streaming
Introduction to Apache Cassandra for distributed data storage
Spark Applications in Policy Study
Use cases and examples of Spark in policy analysis and decision-making
Developing and optimizing Spark-based solutions for policy-related tasks

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Machine Learning for Public Policy
courses.description: This course introduces students to the machine learning concepts and techniques that are relevant to policy analytics. Major topics include linear regression, predictive modeling, classification, resampling methods, dimension reduction techniques, principal component analysis, smoothing splines. Additional topics such as decision trees, support vector machines and clustering methods may also be introduced. Students will learn how to employ these methods to conduct supervised and unsupervised learning for social and policy analytics, and gain hands-on experience with real-life data using data science software.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to:
Understand the distinction between supervised and unsupervised learning, and identify appropriate tools to address research questions with “big data”
Make use of the following supervised learning algorithms: linear and logistic regression, K-nearest neighbors, discriminant analysis, cross-validation and bootstrap, shrinkage estimation, generalized additive models, tree-based methods, and support vector machines in social and policy analysis
Apply basic unsupervised procedures including clustering and principal components analysis in social and policy analysis
Appreciate the bias-variance tradeoff and apply model selection methods based on cross-validation and bootstrapping to a prediction challenge
Analyze real-world dataset using data science software
courses.course_syllabus: Major topics include linear regression, predictive modeling, classification, resampling methods, dimension reduction techniques, principal component analysis, smoothing splines. Additional topics such as decision trees, support vector machines and clustering methods may also be introduced.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
- Shah, C. (2023). A Hands-On Introduction to Machine Learning. Cambridge University Press.
- James, G., Witten, D., Hastie, T. and Tibshirani, R (2014). An Introduction to Statistical Learning, 8th printing 2017. New York: Springer.
courses.recommended_readings:
Magallanes, Jose Manuel (2017). Introduction to Data Science for Social and Policy Research: Collecting and Organizing Data with R and Python. New York: Cambridge University Press.
Hastie, T., Tibshirani, R. and Friedman, J (2009). The Elements of Statistical Learning: Data Mining, Inference and Prediction, 2nd Edition.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Collaborative Governance in a Global Context
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with knowledge, skills and applications of collaborative governance in a rapidly changing globalized world. Collaborative governance is broadly defined as the processes and structures of public policy decision making and management that engage people constructively across the boundaries of public, private and civic society for a public purpose that could not otherwise be accomplished. With the increasingly limited role of government in governance, the ability of policymakers to collaborate with non-state actors across levels and boundaries becomes critical for addressing policy challenges. The course focuses on how collaborative governance can build consensus and deliberative purposes of public policy and governance through studying its formats, process, rationales, concepts and outcomes as well as evaluation of its effectiveness and dilemma. The course also intends to nurture students to have a responsible and reflective role in society and to pursue a better governance.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
Understand how collaborative governance can benefit the policy making and implementation from multiple theoretical perspectives
Understand the cooperation and negotiation among governments, the public and other key stakeholders
Establish a knowledge structure of collaborative governance encompassing the dynamics in a global context
Have the idea of pracitical collaborative governance by investigating the global cases of collaborative governance
courses.course_syllabus:
Introducing collaborative governance in a rapidly changing globalized world
Understanding public policy decision making process in an interactive and global context
Distinguish different actors and level of analysis in collaborative governance
Challenges and difficulties in international cooperation and public policy problem-solving
Future development and innovative mode
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.

Zed Books Ltd.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Data Science and Regulation
courses.description: The course focuses on the regulatory issues and concerns when the governments take data science as a paradigm to enhance the capacity of public policy. Advance in data science radically transforms the way data can be handled and utilized, and inevitably generates new regulatory concerns and debates due to the clash of competing values and interests. For example, while privacy and citizen rights advocates strive to decrease unexpected uses of data, many scientists and institutions may attempt to use data to design and evaluate public policies in order to maximize its effectiveness. This course discusses theoretical approaches to regulations from multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary approaches for the analysis of regulatory institutions, practices and ideas in data regulation as well as the dillemma between utilization of data and its protection, accessibility and transparency.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Understand the general use of data science in public policy and governance
Understand the theories, approaches and mechanism of regulation of using data science
Understand the regulation in selected policy areas of data science, such as health care, transportation, security, law enforcement etc.
Construct a comprehensive picture of how data science can help regulation, or to be regulated and the balance among critical concerns and issues such as privacy, national interest and human rights
courses.course_syllabus:
Theories and concepts of regulation
Hazard-based regulation vs. risk-based regulation
Regulatory tools and data regulation
Case studies of data regulation in major policy areas
How national context affects regulatory setting and implementation
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
ITGP Privacy Team. (2017). EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR): An Implementation and Compliance Guide. Ely: IT Governance Ltd.

Reins, L. (2019). Regulating New Technologies in Uncertain Times. The Hague: T.M.C. Asser Press.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Extended Reality (XR) for Data Visualization and Policy Narratives
courses.description: In an era of technological advancement, AR/VR transcends traditional media types such as images, videos, text, and audio, offering a new medium for applications in data science and policy studies. This course explores the diverse applications of AR/VR technology in data visualization and policy narratives. Students gain practical skills in creating AR/VR experiences for visualizing complex data, crafting compelling narratives, and communicating policy insights. They will learn about AR/VR systems, principles for immersive experiences, human-centered design for AR/VR, and game development using cutting-edge platforms such as Unity. This course illuminates the potential of AR/VR as a powerful tool for visualizing ideas and communicating information with unparalleled depth and clarity. This course is ideal for students who are interested in exploring innovative applications of emerging technologies in data visualization, idea presentation, and policy communication and seek to harness AR/VR technology to innovate in these domains.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Describe the capabilities and limitations of AR/VR technology and their applications in policy design and analysis.
Use game engines to create AR/VR applications.
Use AR/VR for visualizing ideas and communicating information.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to AR/VR Technology
What is AR/VR technology?
Different types of AR/VR systems and their capabilities.
Examples of AR/VR applications in policy design and analysis.
Unity for AR/VR App Development
Introduction to Unity as a development platform for AR/VR apps.
Fundamentals of creating AR/VR apps in Unity.
Best practices for AR/VR app design.
AR/VR Data Visualization and Policy Narratives
Applying AR/VR technology to data visualization and policy narratives.
Hands-on experience using AR/VR tools to present ideas.
Collaboration and teamwork in AR/VR app development.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Smart Cities and Internet of Things
courses.description: This course will introduce the concept of Smart Cities and explore how the Internet of Things (IoT) can help address urbanization challenges. Students will gain an understanding of the different components of IoT for Smart Cities, including sensor technologies, communication technologies, big data analytics, and security. The course will cover topics such as devices and communication protocols for IoT networks, big data analytics in the context of the IoT paradigm, IoT-enabled electric vehicles in smart cities, and blockchain technology for security and privacy in IoT. This course is ideal for students who wish to explore the opportunities of IoT in building a smarter city.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Define and describe the concept of Smart Cities and IoT.
Understand the role of IoT in addressing city challenges.
Describe the different components of IoT for Smart Cities, including IoT devices and sensors, communication technologies, big data analytics, and security.
Analyze security and privacy challenges in IoT and evaluate the use of blockchain technology to address them.
Evaluate the potential benefits and challenges of Smart City applications.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Smart Cities and IoT
Overview of Smart Cities and IoT
Key challenges in Smart Cities
IoT solutions for Smart Cities
2. Communication Technologies and Protocols for IoT
Types of IoT devices and sensors
General classification of communication protocols for IoT networks
Technical details and specific advantages and limitations of different protocols
3. Big Data Analytics in IoT
Introduction to Big Data in IoT
Dimension reduction techniques for Big Data analytics in IoT
4. Security and Privacy for IoT
Overview of security and privacy challenges in IoT
Introduction to blockchain technology for security and privacy in IoT
5. Future Trends and Challenges
Emerging IoT technologies and their impact on Smart Cities
Potential social, economic, and environmental impacts of IoT in urban environments
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Computer Simulation for Policymaking
courses.description: This course introduces the fundamentals of systems modeling and simulation, which are increasingly popular tools for developing, implementing, and evaluating public policy. The course will expose students to diverse system modeling and simulation approaches and emphasize their applications in policymaking to equip them with the skills they will need to conduct technically-focused policy analysis. Teaching is conducted through class lectures and tutorials related to simulation software applications (e.g., Anylogic). This course is ideal for individuals with prior programming experience interested in exploring computer simulation’s potential for policy design and analysis.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to
Understand the application background of system modelling and simulation.
List out examples of simulation applications / studies.
Interpret simulation results
Use commercial software packages (e.g., Anylogic) to construct, verify and validate models of the given systems
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to computer simulation for policymaking
Overview of simulation techniques and their role in policymaking
Explanation of system modelling and simulation concepts
Overview of different types of simulations and their applications
Model Development with Anylogic
Formulating policy problems into models
Introduction to Anylogic simulation software
Data collection, analysis, and visualization for model development using Anylogic
Model design and validation using Anylogic
Agent-Based Modeling
Introduction to agent-based modeling
Designing agent-based models using Anylogic
Simulating complex interactions between agents
Discrete Event Simulation
Introduction to discrete event simulation
Designing discrete event models using Anylogic
Simulating dynamic processes over time
Model Implementation
Implementation of agent-based and discrete event models using Anylogic
Verification and validation of the simulation results
Interpretation of simulation results
Sensitivity Analysis
Performing sensitivity analysis to determine the impact of different variables on simulation results
Identifying key variables and their influence on policymaking
Policy Evaluation and Presentation
Use of simulation results for policy evaluation
Presentation of simulation results to policymakers
Incorporating simulation results into policy decisions

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Policy Leadership and Entrepreneurship Workshop
courses.description: This course studies how leadership and entrepreneurship are interrelated to create social and political impacts throughout the policy process, in particular, how leadership acts as an important factor to influence the social environment to nurture entrepreneurial activities. Leadership provides social source of influence and vision that one uses to inspire action taken by others, and to mobilize others to achieve a common goal. Entrepreneurship is the recognition of opportunities by coupling needs, wants, resources, and problems with innovative solutions and make changes to society. With a workshop format, the course provides students more interactive experience to equip them with the mindset, skills, and strategies of policy leadership and entrepreneurship. Policy leaders and entrepreneurs will be invited to serve as guest speakers in order to offer students the opportunities to learn from their practical experience.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
Understand the concepts and theories of leadership and their practice in public policy
Understand the concepts and theories of policy entrepreneurship and their practice
Understand the relationships between policy leadership and entrepreneurship and how to integrate the two concepts to search for and respond to opportunities to have better results and innovations
Apply the framework of policy leadership and entrepreneurship in major cases and policy areas across local and global contexts
courses.course_syllabus:
Foundation of policy leadership and entrepreneurship
Policy leadership and entrepreneurship in Hong Kong and major countries
Global governance and network under policy leadership and entrepreneurship
Application of policy leadership and entrepreneurship in major policy areas
Future research and agenda of policy leadership and entrepreneurship

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Social Network Analysis for Public Policy
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students to the concepts and methods of social network analysis (SNA), including network types, levels of analysis, data collection, descriptive methods and inferential methods, and their applications in public policy, such as policy agenda setting, policy network, advocacy coalition, policy learning and diffusion, and policy implementation. It also familiarizes students with network analysis software (e.g., Python and/or R). This course is ideal for students with basic knowledge of data analytics who are interested in understanding and using SNA in public policy studies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Understand the concepts and methods of social network analysis.
Describe the applications of social network analysis in public policy.
Use
network analysis software (e.g., Python and/or R) to do social network analysis.
Apply social network analysis to address actual policy issues and make better policy.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Natural Language Processing for Public Policy
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students to some common methods of Natural Language Processing (NLP), including text classification, topic modelling, text summarization, event extraction and text scaling, and their applications in public policy, such as data collection for evidence-based policymaking, interpretation of political decisions, policy communication, and investigation of policy effects. It also familiarizes students with some of the most useful Python libraries for NLP, for example, transformers, stanza and spaCy. Ethical issues are also discussed. This course is ideal for students with basic knowledge of machine learning who are interested in understanding and using NLP tools in data-driven policymaking.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Understand the principles behind the common NLP methods.
Use the common Python libraries for NLP to solve problems.
Describe the (mis-)uses of NLP in public policy.
Apply NLP tools to address actual policy issues and make better policy.

Topic Modelling: Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA), Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Internship
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide students with practical work experiences in the application of both data science and policy studies learned in DSPS programme. Students will be given opportunities to observe and experience the management operations and to have hands-on experience in public sector, non-government organizations (NGOs), private sector etc., and to experience the work life in the sector, as well as to nurture students’ practical skills. It is recommended that the internship to be conducted in summer holiday, i.e. June to August, after finishing year two studies in the block mode (i.e. 5 days x 8 hours). DSPS Programme will deploy work units, agencies, or organizations that provide internships relevant to the general course objectives. Meanwhile, students are encouraged to explore opportunities of internship to fit their own specific learning needs. However, all self-selected internship must comply with the course requirements, and subjected to the approval of DSPS Programme Director. Guidance and assistance will be provided whenever appropriate.During the internship, each student would be guided and assisted by an academic supervisor. The supervisor offers advice and help whenever necessary during the attachment period. At the same time, each student will be receiving guidance and assistance from his/her agency supervisor. Students will submit self-evaluation report to reflect on the experience in the internship. Academic advice will be provided to help students consolidate their learning in the internship.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Apply the learnt theories and knowledges into skills and practices in work experience
Explore different career alternatives before they graduate
Develop good work attitude which is essential to have job success
Develop interpersonal skills, critical thinking skills and problem-solving skills which are applicable in both academic and working environment
courses.course_syllabus: To be decided by the instructor and the internship organization
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings: Nil

, 37-46.
- Sweitzer, H. F., & King, M.A. (2019).
The successful internship : personal, professional, and civic development in experiential learning.
Boston, MA, USA : Cengage.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Advanced Data Visualization
courses.description: This course is designed to equip students with the skills to convey data-driven insights clearly and effectively. The course begins with an introduction to data visualization and perception principles, followed by an overview of visualization design principles, data preparation and exploration, and advanced visualization techniques.Students will also learn about popular visualization tools (e.g., Tableau), virtual and augmented reality technologies, ethics and bias in data visualization, data storytelling, and data visualization for big data. The course concludes with a final project, where students apply the concepts learned throughout the course to create a high-impact data visualization using advanced technologies.This course is ideal for individuals with prior programming experience interested in exploring advanced data visualization techniques and technologies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
Create effective data visualizations that convey complex information in a clear and compelling way.
Apply design principles and best practices to data visualization, including color theory, typography, and layout.
Use advanced visualization techniques such as 3D visualizations, interactive dashboards, and emerging technologies such as virtual and augmented reality (VR/AR).
Identify and avoid common pitfalls and biases in data visualization.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to Data Visualization and Perception Principles
What is data visualization?
The importance of data visualization in decision-making
Perception principles and how they affect data visualization
Fundamentals of Visualization Design
Principles of design, including color theory, layout, typography, and chart types
Best practices for creating effective visualizations
Critique of existing visualizations
Data Preparation and Exploration
Data cleaning, transformation, and aggregation
Exploratory data analysis techniques
Data preparation and exploration with Python and Tableau
Advanced Visualization Techniques / Tools
Emerging visualization techniques
Overview of popular visualization tools such as Tableau, Power BI, and D3.js
Comparison of different tools and their capabilities
Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) in Data Visualization
Introduction to VR and AR technologies
VR and AR applications in data visualization
Hands-on experience with VR and AR tools
Visualization Best Practices and Ethics
Best practices for visualizing data and presenting insights effectively
Avoiding common visualization pitfalls
Ethical considerations and potential biases in data visualization

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: AI for Social Good
courses.description: This course introduces students with basic coding skills to modern Artificial Intelligence (AI) and its societal impacts. It focuses on the techniques of deep learning and reinforcement learning, the workhorse of modern data-centric AI technologies and their applications. Ethical challenges and policy implications of these powerful AI technologies and applications are critically discussed and their positive and negative impacts on achieving the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) critically evaluated. The main concern of the course is how to ensure that these disruptive modern AI technologies are used to do good, rather than bad, to society. An emphasis is put on the need for dedicated regulatory AI policies, both at the national and international levels.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to Modern AI Technology
Deep neural networks and deep learning
Reinforcement learning
Applications (facial recognition systems, self-driving cars, ChatGPT)
AI for Social Good and the Sustainable Development Goals
AI and the UN’s SDGs
AI and Ethics
Ethics for AI
AI Ethics
Ethical AI
AI Policy
​National AI Strategies
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Advanced Applications of Data Science in Public Policy
courses.description: This is a special-topics course on advanced applications of data science in decision making, visualization, research, analytics and presentation techniques to inform policy decision-making. Topics covered would depend on knowledge and expertise of the instructor, and the latest development and innovations in the field. Students will be equipped with the most advanced capacities and methods to conduct data analytics related to policy decisions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to:
Explain the data strategies from decision-makers’ perspective
Apply the advance data science skills for conducting policy analytics and propose data-driven solutions
Given a policy research question, use relevant data to test hypotheses, conduct statistical inference, and interpret results with data science software
Apply the visualizing tools to obtain policy insights from the data, and to present the analytics results
Gain hands-on experience of writing and presenting a policy research paper on solving real-world problems
courses.course_syllabus: Topics covered would depend on knowledge and expertise of the instructor, and the latest development and innovations in the field.
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
Kampakis, Stylianos (2020). The Decision Maker's Handbook to Data Science. 2nd ed. Berkeley, CA: Apress.
Loth, Alexander (2019). Visual Analytics with Tableau. Canada: Wiley & Sons, Inc.
Rahman, Azizur (2020). Statistics for Data Science and Policy Analysis. Singapore: Springer Nature.
courses.recommended_readings: Berman, Evan M., and XiaoHu Wang (2018). Essential Statistics for Public Managers and Policy Analysts. Fourth ed. Thousand Oaks, California: SAGE Publications.

courses.subject: DSPS
courses.title: Data, Evidence and Public Policy
courses.description: This course examines the fundamental principles and practices of evidence-based policymaking, emphasizing the role of data and empirical evidence in public policy design, implementation, and evaluation. Students will learn how to critically analyze policy issues through multiple lenses - empirical, normative, and practical - while developing skills in policy evaluation methodologies. The course covers the entire policy cycle, from problem identification to impact assessment, with particular attention to data collection, causal inference, and evaluation techniques. Through case studies across various policy domains, students will explore how evidence informs policy decisions and shapes public sector outcomes. The course combines theoretical frameworks with practical applications, preparing students to become sophisticated consumers and producers of policy evidence.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
1. Analyze and critically evaluate different types of evidence (quantitative, qualitative, and mixed methods) used in policy decision-making, understanding their strengths, limitations, and appropriate applications
2. Apply fundamental methodologies in policy evaluation, including experimental and quasi-experimental designs, cost-benefit analysis, and impact assessment frameworks
3. Transform complex data and research findings into clear, actionable policy recommendations, demonstrating effective communication of evidence to diverse stakeholders
4. Assess the practical, political, and institutional challenges in implementing evidence-based policies, including considerations of feasibility, equity, and effectiveness
5. Design and conduct basic policy evaluations using appropriate methodological tools, while adhering to ethical standards in data collection, analysis, and interpretation
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to Policy and Programme Evaluation; Persona of Evaluation Cases
Week 2: Fundamental Policy and Programme Evaluation Design
Week 3: Systematic Review in Policy and Programme Evaluation I
Week 4: Systematic Review in Policy and Programme Evaluation II; Programme Evaluation Theory I
Week 5: Programme Evaluation Theory II
Week 6: Assignment Week
Week 7: Seminar on mini-evaluation study
Week 8: Evaluating Complexity
Week 9: Evaluating Impact I
Week 10: Evaluating Impact II
Week 11: Student-led Seminar Session; Advanced Topics on Policy and Programme Evaluation I
Weel 12: Advanced Topics on Policy and Programme Evaluation II
Week 13: Mini-evaluation Project Presentation
courses.feedback_evaluation: At least one course evaluation survey, to be conducted usually in the last week of class.
courses.required_readings:
Gertler, P. J., Martinez, S., Premand, P., Rawlings, L. B., & Vermeersch, C. M. (2016).
Impact evaluation in practice
. World Bank Publications.
Linfield, K. J., & Posavac, E. J. (2018).
Program evaluation: Methods and case studies
. Routledge.
Mertens, D. M., & Wilson, A. T. (2018).
Program evaluation theory and practice
. Guilford Publications.
Rossi, P. H., Lipsey, M. W., & Henry, G. T. (2018).
Evaluation: A systematic approach (8
th
Ed)
. Sage publications.

courses.title: Graduation Capstone Project I

meetings.instructor:

Professor CHAN Chee Hon, 
Professor QIU Lin, 
Professor WONG Wai Ho

Dr. WONG Kwong Cheong,

Professor WONG Wai Ho

courses.description: The graduation capstone project is about generating innovative ideas and implementing actionable knowledge to create impactful solutions. It offers students the opportunity to conduct a project on a selected topic under supervision related to data science and policy studies. While students are expected to integrate and apply what they have learned in the courses, internship, overseas exchanges and other learning opportunities, they are expected to address a real-world issue and to formulate feasible solutions and/or policy recommendations for the issue. Students are expected to meet their supervisor regularly, present their findings and exhibit their final product in any formats after developing a mutual consent between students and supervisor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
Identify a topic with a specific client in mind for generating innovative ideas and implementing actionable knowledge to create impactful solutions
Identify previous academic works and innovative projects as references to their topic
Consult client on the project topic, concerns and expectation
Plan and organize the whole project design
Collect and analyse data
Present findings and policy recommendations
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Identify the topic
2. Literature review
3. Client consultation and expectations assessment
4. Project design
5. Data collection and analysis
6. Presentation of findings and policy implementation
courses.feedback_evaluation: To be decided by the course teacher concerned based on the topic selected
courses.required_readings: To be decided by the course teacher concerned based on the topic selected
courses.recommended_readings: To be decided by the course teacher concerned based on the topic selected

courses.description: This course provides an in-depth analysis of important topics in data science and policy studies. The focus of the course may vary according to the area of expertise of the instructor and the interests of the class.
courses.learning_outcomes: This is an open-ended course offering students the opportunity to learn a specialized and important subject area of data science and policy studies at the 4000 course level that is not yet covered by our existing courses. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to understand the major concepts and theories of the subject area and apply them in analyzing key policy problems for formulating effective and feasible solutions
